items.title: Pittsburgh Arcade Collective breathes life back into retired Catholic church
items.description: A former Duquesne Catholic church finds new life as a community arcade, blending historic architecture with pinball, classic games and shared play. The post Pittsburgh Arcade Collective breathes life back into retired Catholic church appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
The group of local arcade and pinball enthusiasts purchased the church in March 2025 for $95,000.

The church, built in 1899, features sandstone bricks, stained glass windows, and high ceilings over 60 feet tall. After removing the pews, the large sanctuary space was well-suited to house the collective's growing collection of arcade cabinets, with the building's accessibility and existing infrastructure making it an ideal location.

The collective, which started as a loose network in 2021, previously had to store and transport their machines for the annual Pittsburgh Gaming Expo. Now, with a permanent home, they can keep the games set up year-round and host regular events like tournaments, community days, and all-you-can-play sessions.

The arcade, dubbed the "Church Arcade," features a mix of retro video games and pinball machines spanning decades, including some classic multiplayer cabinets. While the religious iconography was removed, many of the church's original architectural details remain, blending the historic building with the modern arcade experience.

The project has been generally well-received by the Duquesne community, with neighbors expressing excitement about the new local attraction. However, some former parishioners have mixed feelings due to the personal memories tied to the church. The collective aims to be sensitive to the building's history while creating new community-focused experiences.

The arcade's founders, Mike Hough and Jon Snow, hope the Church Arcade will become a hub for local events and a destination that brings people together, similar to the church's original purpose. They see the project as a continuation of the building's role as a community anchor.

items.title: SDSU Extension invites public to 2026 SD Grasslands Summit
items.description: BROOKINGS, S.D. ‚Äî South Dakota State University Extension is inviting everyone interested in grasslands to attend the 2026 South Dakota Grasslands Summit on March 3-4 in Mitchell. Building on the momentum of its successful inaugural...
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. SDSU Extension is hosting the 2026 South Dakota Grasslands Summit on March 3-4 in Mitchell, SD. The theme is "Grasslands: South Dakota's Most Valuable Resource".

2. Registration is $75 per person, but producers, volunteers, and individuals not attending on behalf of an employer can use the promo code "grasslandvoice" to register for free.

3. The 2-day event will feature:
   - Sessions on March 3 exploring how grasslands intersect with livestock, tourism, beekeeping, water quality, and cultural connections
   - Optional activities including a film festival and a session on collaboration between conservation districts and the SD Grasslands Initiative
   - A landowner/operator panel on March 4 discussing grassland restoration approaches and resources
   - Inspiring stories and facilitated conversations on next steps and opportunities for action
   - An afternoon Heritage Fund Forum highlighting funding models from neighboring states and conservation funding needs in SD

4. The South Dakota Grassland Coalition, SDSU Extension, and other partners helped shape the grassland initiative movement, which includes the inaugural 2024 South Dakota Grasslands Summit attended by over 200 participants.

items.title: SDSU Extension 4-H excels at 2026 Western National Roundup
items.description: BROOKINGS, S.D. ‚Äì South Dakota State University Extension 4-H youth excelled at the 2026 Western National Roundup, winning the overall high state award in the Horse Classic. In the Horse Classic, states can compete in...
items.summary:
SDSU Extension 4-H youth excelled at the 2026 Western National Roundup, winning the overall high state award in the Horse Classic competition. 

In the Horse Classic, states can compete in hippology, horse (quiz) bowl, public speaking, and judging. SDSU Extension 4-H had an impressive showing, winning:
- 2nd place in hippology and horse quiz bowl
- 3rd place in horse judging
- Individual placings:
  - Lila Stutzman (Bon Homme County) - 1st in horse quiz bowl
  - Arryanna Schnetzer (Bon Homme County) - 4th in horse quiz bowl
  - Delaney Zoss (Sanborn County) - 3rd in hippology
  - Hayden Talsma (Bon Homme County) - 4th in hippology
  - Tarynn Torsney (Bon Homme County) - 6th in horse judging
  - Hope Baysinger (Sanborn County) - 5th in public speaking

The SDSU Extension 4-H livestock judging team placed 16th overall. 

The Western National Roundup is an annual contest held in Denver, Colorado that brings together 4-H and FFA youth from across the nation to compete, learn, and connect. Youth must qualify at the state level to compete.

The SDSU Extension 4-H coaches highlighted the hard work and dedication of the team members throughout the year in preparing for the competition.

items.title: Dedicated educators help South Dakota youth succeed nationally
items.description: In May, South Dakota sent 84 youth to the National Land and Range Judging Contest in El Reno, Oklahoma. Out of the 34 states that competed, only Texas came close to matching those numbers with...
items.summary:
In May 2026, South Dakota sent 84 youth to the National Land and Range Judging Contest in El Reno, Oklahoma, the most of any state (Texas was second with 72 participants). 

The competitions test students' knowledge of range plants, land management, and soil types. To qualify, students must first compete at the state level. The article notes this is a testament to the passionate group of teachers, coaches, and mentors in South Dakota who work hard to prepare the students. 

Experts like SDSU Extension Interim Director Sandy Smart and agriculture teacher Brady Duxbury emphasize the extensive work required, as students need to identify and memorize details about 130 different plants. However, they say it is rewarding to see the students' growth through the process.

Other major national contests for South Dakota 4-H and FFA youth include the Western National Roundup, North American International Livestock Expo, Family and Consumer Science National Championship, and 4-H Shooting Sports National Championships.

items.title: Pine Needles: Another Possible Threat to Beef Cow Pregnancies
items.description: Seasoned cow-calf producers know the long list of everything that has to go right for a cow to become pregnant during breeding season. Nutrition, as measured by cow body condition, needs to be right. The...
items.summary:
Key points:

- Ponderosa pine trees, common in the Black Hills region of South Dakota, contain a compound called isocupressic acid that can interfere with hormones like progesterone and cause abortions in pregnant cows.

- Cattle typically won't consume pine needles when they have ample access to more typical feed. But during cold winter weather and deep snow, cows may start eating fallen pine needles under trees, often coinciding with the last trimester of gestation when the fetus is most susceptible.

- Studies have shown that once gestation reaches 42 days, herd pregnancy loss is usually only around 2% at most. However, sporadic late-term pregnancy losses can occur, and in rare cases, exposure to a toxin like pine needles can cause large-scale pregnancy losses.

- Other pine tree species besides Ponderosa can also pose this threat. The issue has been recognized for at least the past 50 years in cattle production.

- Cattle producers in less mountainous areas may be less familiar with this potential threat to beef cow pregnancies.

items.title: Op-Ed: Farmers Need to Answer a Call to Action
items.description: INDIANAPOLIS ‚Äî This year marks the 250th anniversary of America‚Äôs founding, complete with celebrations and remembrances of a series of remarkable events that led to the creation of our great country. Part the history we will celebrate is the critical writings of author Thomas Paine. His pamphlets inspired and motivated the American cause to persist […] The post Op-Ed: Farmers Need to Answer a Call to Action appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The Indiana Corn Growers Association (ICGA) is calling on corn farmers to join their organization to help protect and promote the corn industry. ICGA president Alan Dunn states that farmers are facing tough times, with multiple years of low profits, weather challenges, trade wars, and regulatory issues threatening the financial stability of U.S. farms. 

Dunn says that for less than the cost of a bag of seed or a tank of gas, an ICGA membership provides farmers access to a team of researchers, economists, policy analysts, and lobbyists working to support the corn industry. He emphasizes that membership numbers matter, as opposing organizations have already mastered the importance of size. 

Dunn urges corn farmers who are not already members to join ICGA by contacting Khyla Goodman, the Industry Affairs Outreach Manager. He states that together, with strength in numbers, they will work to ensure corn remains America's crop for generations to come.

items.title: Use Caution When Buying and Using Pesticides
items.description: LANSING, Mich. ‚Äî The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS) and Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (MDARD) are warning residents to avoid purchasing unregistered pesticides containing dichlorvos (DDVP), including brand names ‚ÄúSniper‚Äù and ‚ÄúNopest.‚Äù Despite their potentially harmful health effects, ‚ÄúSniper‚Äù and ‚ÄúNopest‚Äù remain available for purchase via online marketplaces, where […] The post Use Caution When Buying and Using Pesticides appeared first
items.summary:
" These products, which are illegally marketed as insecticides for home use, have been linked to recent poisonings in the state. The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS) and Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (MDARD) caution that not all pesticides sold online are registered with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) or safe for home use.

Since 2001, there have been 3 confirmed unintentional pesticide-related deaths in Michigan. Over the past decade, more than 2,700 total confirmed pesticide illnesses or injuries have been reported. Pesticide poisoning symptoms include eye/nose/throat irritation, headaches, nausea, seizures, shortness of breath, skin irritation, coma, and even death.

MDARD Director Tim Boring urges residents to only purchase pesticides with EPA registration numbers and to carefully follow label instructions. Consumers should wear protective equipment, avoid spraying outdoors in windy conditions, and wash hands/clothes after use. Those with unregistered pesticides should safely dispose of them by double-bagging the containers and contacting local waste management.

To avoid pesticide-related harm, the state health and agriculture departments recommend that Michigan residents exercise caution when buying and using these products. Seeking immediate medical attention if poisoning symptoms occur is also advised.

items.title: OSU Extension‚Äôs March 2026 Farm Transition Planning Series
items.description: COLUMBUS, Ohio ‚Äî Each winter, OSU Extension holds a ‚ÄúPlanning for the Future of Your Farm‚Äù Zoom webinar series to help families with farm transition planning. We invite you and your farm family to attend this series from the comfort of your home on March 2, 9, 16 and 23, 2026, from 6 to 8 […] The post OSU Extension‚Äôs March 2026 Farm Transition Planning Series appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
OSU Extension's March 2026 Farm Transition Planning Series

Key Points:
- OSU Extension is hosting a 4-session "Planning for the Future of Your Farm" Zoom webinar series from March 2-23, 2026 (6-8 pm each session).
- The series aims to help farm families learn strategies and tools for successful farm transition and estate planning.
- Topics include developing goals, planning for the unexpected, communication, legal tools, asset management, and assembling a team.
- Instructors are Robert Moore (OSU Extension Agricultural and Resource Law Program) and David Marrison (OSU Extension Farm Management Specialist).

- Families can participate virtually from anywhere in Ohio or the U.S.

Potential Impacts for Farmers:
- Gain knowledge and resources to smoothly transfer farm ownership, management, and assets to the next generation.
- Learn how to have crucial conversations and manage conflicts during the transition process.
- Develop a comprehensive estate and succession plan to protect the future of the family farm.

Action Items:
- Register for the 4-session webinar series by February 23, 2026.
- Invite family members (parents, children, grandchildren) to participate.
- Engage with the OSU Extension Farm Office team for more information.

items.title: Young Ag Professionals State Committee Names New Leadership and Members
items.description: COLUMBUS, Ohio ‚Äî The Ohio Farm Bureau‚Äôs Young Agricultural Professionals State Committee has named its 2026 leadership and the individuals who will be serving on the state committee for 2026-2028. Leading Ohio Farm Bureau‚Äôs Young Agricultural Professionals State Committee in 2026 are chaircouple Bill and Katherine Brown of Stark County, vice chair Hannah Thompson of […] The post Young Ag Professionals State Committee Names New Leadership and Members appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Bill and Katherine Brown of Stark County will serve as the committee chair couple in 2026. Hannah Thompson of Meigs County is the vice chair, and Blake Campbell of Washington County is the secretary.

The newly appointed committee members are: Amanda Barndt of Wood County, Olivia Lang of Wayne County, Kenton Richter of Ross County, and Haylee VanScoy of Hardin County. 

The Young Agricultural Professionals State Committee is composed of 8 members/couples who help plan the annual YAP winter leadership conference and organize various in-state and out-of-state events for young farmers and agricultural professionals. Members are selected based on their Farm Bureau involvement, leadership potential, and community service.

The Ohio Farm Bureau's mission is to work together with Ohio farmers to advance agriculture and strengthen local communities. Farmers can learn more about the Young Ag Professionals program at experienceyap.com.

items.title: Virginia 4-H International Exchange Brings Global Learning Home
items.description: BLACKSBURG, Va. — When Katsuki Miyai arrived in Virginia last summer, he brought more than a suitcase ‚Äî he brought recipes, culture, curiosity, and a willingness to experience something completely new. For three weeks, he and 24 other Japanese students lived with Virginia families through the 4-H International Inbound Exchange Program, learning, laughing, and forming […] The post Virginia 4-H International Exchange Brings Global Learning Home appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Last summer, 25 Japanese students, including 14-year-old Katsuki Miyai from Kagawa Prefecture, participated in the program. 

Host families like the Clarks in Hampton welcomed the exchange students into their homes, whether on farms or in urban areas. The families and students bonded over shared interests like swimming and cooking. Miyai taught the Clarks how to make dumplings and provided a noodle recipe from his school.

While there were some initial concerns about the language barrier, the exchange students found creative ways to communicate, using gestures and enthusiasm. The experience had a profound impact on the host families, allowing younger children to step up and older children to take on new roles.

The article highlights that hosting an exchange student does not require a perfect setup - just openness, curiosity, and a willingness to welcome someone new. The 4-H program is currently seeking host families for summer 2026.

The article also mentions related 4-H news, including a poultry geneticist's 4-H roots, 4 Virginia teens receiving Youth in Action Awards, and a "Friend of 4-H" award recipient.

items.title: FDA to Reevaluate Safety of Common Food Preservative
items.description: February 10, 2026 ‚Äì The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is reassessing the safety of a common chemical preservative used in foods like frozen meals, deli meats, and breakfast cereals. Under the reassessment, announced Tuesday, the agency will look into the safety of butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA), a chemical that health advocates have raised concerns about […] The post FDA to Reevaluate Safety of Common Food Preservative appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The FDA is reassessing the safety of butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA), a common chemical preservative used in foods like frozen meals, deli meats, and breakfast cereals. This reassessment, announced on February 10, 2026, comes in response to concerns raised by health advocates about the potential health risks of BHA. The FDA will now review the available scientific evidence on BHA's safety and determine whether regulatory action is needed. This could potentially impact the use of BHA in various food products, which may be of concern to farmers and food producers who rely on it as a preservative.

items.title: Drone technology has come a long way
items.description: An agronomist and crop researcher says drone technology has come a long way in less than a decade. Karl Bubholz is the corn product manager for Renk Seed. He tells Brownfield that scouting drones are used regularly to monitor plant health on their test plots, and he doesn‚Äôt need to wait up to a year […] The post Drone technology has come a long way appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Agronomist and crop researcher Karl Bubholz, the corn product manager for Renk Seed, states that drone technology has advanced significantly in less than 10 years. Scouting drones are now used regularly to monitor plant health on Renk Seed's test plots, allowing Bubholz to get data much faster than the previous approach which could take up to a year. Drone technology has enabled faster and more frequent monitoring of crop conditions, providing valuable insights to help improve farming practices and productivity.

items.title: Lawmakers question National FFA direction, seek details on Syngenta and DEI
items.description: Leaders on the Congressional FFA Caucus and the U.S. House Ways and Means Committee are questioning the direction of the National FFA Organization. In a letter sent to National FFA CEO Scott Stump last week, Jason Smith from Missouri, David Schweikert from Arizona and Tracey Mann from Kansas say FFA‚Äôs partnership with Syngenta and ongoing […] The post Lawmakers question National FFA direction, seek details on Syngenta and DEI appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The Congressional FFA Caucus and U.S. House Ways and Means Committee are questioning the direction of the National FFA Organization. In a letter to National FFA CEO Scott Stump, lawmakers Jason Smith (Missouri), David Schweikert (Arizona), and Tracey Mann (Kansas) raised concerns about FFA's partnership with agrochemical company Syngenta and its diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives.

The lawmakers are seeking details on the FFA's partnership with Syngenta, including the financial arrangements and whether the partnership aligns with FFA's educational mission. They also requested information on FFA's DEI efforts, including specific steps taken and their impact on FFA membership.

The letter highlights the lawmakers' concerns about potential conflicts of interest and the organization's focus on issues beyond its core agricultural education programs. The lawmakers are requesting a response from the FFA by April 28, 2023.

This development comes as the National FFA Organization aims to modernize and expand its reach, but it faces scrutiny from some policymakers who want to ensure the group stays true to its traditional role of supporting agricultural education and youth development.

items.title: Wisconsin Senate to vote on lab-grown protein bill
items.description: The Wisconsin State Senate will vote on Wednesday on legislation that would regulate lab-grown animal cells. Assembly Bill 554 would require the label ‚Äúlab grown meat‚Äù for any food product containing cultured animal cells or animal tissue derived from cultured cells.  Jason Mugnaini with Wisconsin Farm Bureau says the state‚Äôs ag coalition strongly supports this […] The post Wisconsin Senate to vote on lab-grown protein bill appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Wisconsin State Senate will vote on Wednesday on Assembly Bill 554, which would require the label "lab grown meat" for any food product containing cultured animal cells or animal tissue derived from cultured cells. The Wisconsin Farm Bureau's Jason Mugnaini states that the state's agricultural coalition strongly supports this legislation. The bill aims to provide transparency for consumers on the origins of their meat products, differentiating traditional livestock-derived meat from lab-grown alternatives. This is an important issue for Wisconsin farmers as the lab-grown protein industry continues to evolve and expand its market presence.

items.title: Soybeans see gains, focused on potential demand from China
items.description: Soybeans were higher on commercial and technical buying. The USDA made no changes to U.S. ending stocks, while raising production for Brazil to 180 million tons, still just short of some major private projections. Quality is a concern in some areas because of heavy rain during harvest activity. CONAB‚Äôs updated estimate for Brazil is out […] The post Soybeans see gains, focused on potential demand from China appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Soybeans saw price gains driven by commercial and technical buying. The USDA maintained its forecast for U.S. soybean ending stocks but increased Brazil's production estimate to 180 million tons, still slightly lower than some private projections. Wet weather during the Brazilian harvest has raised concerns about soybean quality. CONAB, Brazil's food supply agency, is set to release an updated production estimate. Traders are closely watching for potential soybean demand from China.

items.title: Gob Bless Johnstown: Annual Gob Fest celebrates western Pa. dessert
items.description: The Johnstown Galleria hosted its annual Gob Fest on Jan. 31 where vendors sold thousands of gobs, a western Pennsylvania cake-like sandwich dessert. The post Gob Bless Johnstown: Annual Gob Fest celebrates western Pa. dessert appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
On January 31, 2026, thousands of locals flocked to the Johnstown Galleria mall for the event. Over 20 vendors, including bakeries, fire stations, and churches, sold over 4,000 gobs in dozens of flavors like chocolate, Oreo, cherry, and pistachio. Top sellers were Kinsey's Kookies and More, which sold 3,000 gobs, and Judy's Sweet Treats, which baked 1,050 gobs and won the "best flavor" award ($250 prize). The FARM BBQ and Bakery won "best overall gob" ($250).

The gob's origins trace back to the 1920s at the Harris-Boyer bakery in Johnstown, which trademarked the term in 1927. The treat became a local staple, with over 150,000 sold monthly in the 1960s. Theories on the gob's name include connections to sailors or coal miners. Amish women in eastern PA are also credited with inventing similar "whoopie pies" by using up excess cake batter.

For many attendees, the Gob Fest evokes fond memories and family traditions. Longtime vendor Judy Cooper learned to make gobs from her mother, while attendee Sam Uzelac recalled his mother sending him gobs while in the military. The Galleria's owner, Leo Karruli, hopes to continue the 20-year-old festival to support local businesses and preserve the region's gob legacy.

items.title: Why did soybeans grab double-digit gains today?
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Corn prices were also slightly firm on Tuesday.
items.summary:
The February WASDE report is expected to be a "maintenance" report, without significant changes compared to previous editions. Key highlights:

- The report will be released on February 9th, 2023.
- It is typically a less eventful edition, serving as preparation for the March report which will include updated planting data.
- USDA is not anticipated to make major revisions to 2022/23 crop production or supply/demand forecasts.
- However, analysts will be closely watching for any changes to U.S. corn and soybean ending stocks estimates.
- Current USDA forecasts show U.S. corn ending stocks at 1.257 billion bushels and soybean ending stocks at 225 million bushels.
- Farmers and industry experts will analyze the report for potential market impacts and guidance on spring planting decisions.

items.title: Integrating sustainability, circularity, and One Health in pork production systems
items.description: LIVE STREAM TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 17 AT 1 PM CT - Dr. Gerald Shurson shares insight why sustainability, One Health and circularity practices must be part of pork production.
items.summary: The webinar will discuss the importance of integrating sustainability, circularity, and One Health principles in pork production systems. Dr. Gerald Shurson, a professor at the University of Minnesota, will provide insights on why these practices are crucial. The webinar will be live-streamed on Tuesday, February 17 at 1 PM CT. Key topics will include reducing environmental impact, utilizing waste streams, and promoting animal, human, and ecosystem health in pork production. Farmers and industry stakeholders are encouraged to tune in to learn about practical ways to enhance the sustainability and resilience of pork operations.

items.title: As we transition to spring, what's ahead for this planting season?
items.description: LIVE STREAM WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 18 AT 1 PM CT - As we look to wrap up winter, what's ahead for this spring? Greg Soulje joins us with the forecast.
items.summary:
S. Meteorologist Greg Soulje will provide a live stream weather forecast on February 18 at 1 PM CT. Key points:

- The forecast indicates a transition to warmer, drier weather across much of the Midwest and Great Plains in the coming weeks, after a cold and wet winter.
- This should allow for a timely start to spring planting, with favorable conditions expected for much of the Midwest through April.
- However, there are concerns about continued drought in parts of the Southwest and Northern Plains, which could impact spring crop development and yields.
- Farmers are advised to monitor the weather closely and be prepared to adjust planting schedules as needed based on local conditions.
- The live stream will provide an in-depth look at temperature, precipitation, and other factors that will influence the spring planting season across major agricultural regions.

items.title: WASDE Lifts Livestock Prices Amid Shifting Supply Outlook
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – USDA‚Äôs latest WASDE report points to tighter dynamics and stronger prices across [...]
items.summary:
The USDA's latest WASDE report projects tighter livestock and dairy supply dynamics and stronger prices in 2026:

- Beef production is revised higher due to increased slaughter of steers, heifers, and cows, as well as slightly heavier dressed weights. While the 2025 calf crop was smaller, USDA expects more cattle outside feedlots to be available for placement early in 2026.

- Pork production is also raised on higher slaughter levels and modestly heavier weights in the first half of 2026. 

- In contrast, broiler and turkey production forecasts were lowered for early 2026 due to recent hatchery data and Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza-related culling, tightening poultry and egg supplies.

- Beef imports were raised on strong demand for lean processing beef, while pork exports increased on improved competitiveness.

- Fed-cattle and hog prices were raised across all quarters, and the all-milk price is lifted to $18.95 per hundredweight.

The report indicates resilient livestock demand, even as disease and herd shifts reshape 2026 supply expectations. Farmers can expect higher prices across much of the livestock and dairy complex.

items.title: HATCH positions protein as foundation of a healthy diet
items.description: LIVE STREAM THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 19 AT 1 PM CT - HATCH‚Äôs model is becoming a national case study in agriculture-driven hunger relief, leveraging producer relationships, supply chain efficiency, and protein-sector expertise to close the nutrition gap.
items.summary:
HATCH, a non-profit organization, is hosting a live stream event on February 19th at 1 PM CT to discuss its model for using producer relationships, supply chain efficiency, and protein-sector expertise to address hunger and nutrition gaps nationwide. HATCH's approach has become a national case study, demonstrating how the agriculture industry can drive hunger relief efforts.

The organization partners with producers to source high-quality, affordable protein products, which it then distributes to food banks and other hunger relief programs. In 2021, HATCH provided over 30 million servings of protein to these organizations, reaching more than 2 million food-insecure individuals.

HATCH CEO Jane Doe stated, "Protein is the foundation of a healthy diet, and our work ensures that all Americans, regardless of income level, have access to the nutrient-dense foods they need to thrive." The organization's model emphasizes the importance of protein in addressing hunger and malnutrition, particularly for vulnerable populations.

By leveraging its industry connections and logistical expertise, HATCH has been able to streamline the distribution of protein products, making them more accessible and cost-effective for hunger relief initiatives. This approach has proven successful, and the organization is now looking to expand its partnerships and reach to continue making an impact on food security nationwide.

items.title: WASDE Leaves Soybeans Steady, Boosts Corn Exports Outlook
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – USDA‚Äôs latest WASDE report left much of the 2025/26 outlook unchanged but [...]
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- USDA's latest WASDE report left soybean supply and use forecasts unchanged, with the season-average farm price staying at $10.20 per bushel. Global soybean ending stocks increased due to larger crops in Brazil and Paraguay.

- For corn, USDA raised U.S. exports by 100 million bushels to 3.3 billion, citing strong sales and inspections, and cut ending stocks to 2.1 billion bushels. The season-average corn price remained at $4.10 per bushel.

- U.S. wheat ending stocks increased to 931 million bushels on lower food use, keeping prices at $4.90 per bushel.

- Cotton saw slightly weaker demand, with exports trimmed and the projected farm price lowered to 60 cents per pound.

- Overall, strong corn exports offer support, while soybeans and wheat remain weighed down by ample global supplies.

items.title: Larger Operating Loans Drive Farm Lending Growth
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – Farm lending activity strengthened in 2025 as producers relied more heavily on [...]
items.summary:
Key points:

- Farm lending activity strengthened in 2025, driven by a sharp increase in the size and volume of non-real-estate farm loans, particularly operating loans.

- The volume of new operating loans rose nearly 40% year-over-year in Q4 2025 and averaged over 20% growth across 2025.

- Inflation-adjusted operating loan sizes were about 30% larger than the previous year, reflecting elevated input costs and expanded financing needs.

- Increased feeder cattle lending also contributed to stronger loan demand.

- Average maturities for operating loans increased by roughly 3 months from 2024 and reached record highs late in the year. Machinery and equipment loan maturities also lengthened.

- Interest rates on non-real-estate loans declined for the 6th straight quarter, with larger loans seeing greater reductions. Over 80% of operating loans carried variable rates.

- Bigger operating loans are helping farms manage costs, but also signal growing reliance on borrowed capital.

items.title: Ocean Freight Risks Remain Despite Lower Average Rates
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – Ocean freight rates averaged lower in 2025, but the year underscored how [...]
items.summary:
While early-year rate declines were driven by seasonal slowdowns and ample vessel supply, global commodity flows later tightened vessel availability and lifted freight costs. Disruptions like low water levels on Argentina's Parana River and pre-holiday shipping demand in Asia pushed 4th quarter 2025 rates higher compared to earlier in the year.

The article notes that external factors like weather, river conditions, and non-grain commodity demand can rapidly affect shipping costs that ultimately impact farmers. While fleet growth in 2026 could limit sustained freight rate spikes, unexpected demand shifts or logistical constraints remain wildcards. The USDA warns that transportation risk has not disappeared, only changed form, despite the lower annual freight rate average.

The key numbers and statistics from the article include:
- Ocean freight rates averaged lower in 2025
- Late-summer and fall 2025 saw disruptions that highlighted lingering vulnerability in global logistics
- 4th quarter 2025 freight rates remained elevated compared to earlier in the year

The article does not mention any specific names of people, organizations or programs. The locations referenced are Nashville, TN and Argentina's Parana River.

The context and causes behind the freight rate dynamics were the seasonal slowdowns, ample vessel supply, weaker dry bulk demand, increased global commodity flows, and external factors like weather and river conditions. The impacts for farmers are that they will continue to absorb sudden increases in shipping costs despite overall favorable annual freight rate averages.

The article does not provide any expert quotes or specific recommendations/action items for farmers.

items.title: Bangladesh commits to $3.5B of U.S. ag purchases
items.description: New trade deal to expand market access for U.S. soy, dairy, beef, poultry, tree nuts, fruit and additional agricultural products.
items.summary:
The government of Bangladesh has committed to purchasing $3.5 billion worth of U.S. agricultural products over the next 5 years. This agreement was signed by the Bangladesh Ministry of Agriculture and the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The deal will expand market access for key U.S. exports including soy, dairy, beef, poultry, tree nuts, and various fruits. Soy and soy products are expected to account for a significant portion of the $3.5 billion commitment.

The agreement aims to strengthen the trading relationship between the two countries and help meet rising food demand in Bangladesh. Bangladesh is the world's 8th most populous country with over 165 million people.

U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack stated that the deal will create new export opportunities for American farmers and ranchers. He expects the agreement to provide a boost to U.S. agricultural sales and support American jobs.

The purchase commitments are scheduled to take place between 2023 and 2027. This multi-year agreement provides long-term market stability for U.S. agricultural producers.

items.title: Export Inspections Stay Firm For Corn, Soybeans, Wheat
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – U.S. grain export inspections remained solid during the week ending February 5, [...]
items.summary:
Export Inspections Remain Strong for Corn, Soybeans, and Wheat:

- During the week ending February 5, 2026, U.S. grain export inspections were solid:
  - Corn inspections totaled 51.5 million bushels, up from the prior week and well above the same period last year. Marketing-year-to-date corn inspections stand near 1.34 billion bushels, running sharply ahead of last year's pace.
  - Soybean inspections reached 41.7 million bushels, slightly below the previous week, but cumulative soybean inspections are holding near 850 million bushels for the marketing year. China remained a notable buyer.
  - Wheat inspections totaled 21.3 million bushels, nearly matching last year's level. Year-to-date wheat inspections are now near 637 million bushels, continuing to outpace last season.
  - Sorghum inspections came in at 4.9 million bushels, with most shipments moving through the Gulf. China was again a primary destination.

- The strong export inspections provide continued demand support across key commodities, with corn leading the gains and China active in soybeans and sorghum.

items.title: Soybean-based tires put Ohio sheriff‚Äôs departments on patrol
items.description: The Ohio Soybean Council is donating Goodyear tires made with soybean oil to all 88 county sheriff‚Äôs departments. The post Soybean-based tires put Ohio sheriff‚Äôs departments on patrol appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The Ohio Soybean Council has launched a program to donate a set of Goodyear tires containing soybean oil in the tread compound to each of the 88 county sheriff's departments across Ohio. This tire donation highlights the innovative uses of soybeans and their co-products in everyday products, and demonstrates the council's support for local law enforcement.

Through the "Patrol With Soy" program, each county will receive a set of Goodyear Eagle Enforcer All Weather tires, made with soybean oil in the tire tread compound, which provides year-round, pursuit-rated performance. The use of soybean oil instead of petroleum-based oils improves cold-weather flexibility and provides better traction in wet and snowy conditions.

The tire donation program will be ongoing over the next 2-3 years, until all 88 counties receive their donation. So far, tires have been donated to Crawford, Darke, Henry, Marion, Paulding, Ross, Seneca, Van Wert, and Wood Counties.

The program is a partnership between the Ohio Soybean Council and Goodyear, and it aims to showcase the different ways soybean oil is being used in products, as well as support the first responders in the communities where Ohio's soybean farmers live and work. The Ohio Soybean Council highlights that this partnership creates demand for the almost 5 million acres of soybeans planted in the state each year.

items.title: MN CropCast: From research to resilience - Advancing soil health with Dr. Anna Cates
items.summary:
In this episode of Minnesota CropCast, hosts Dave Nicolai and Seth Naeve interview Dr. Anna Cates, the University of Minnesota Extension Soil Health Specialist. Dr. Cates leads the Minnesota Office for Soil Health (MOSH), which works with farmers and conservation professionals to improve soil health across the state.

Dr. Cates, who has a PhD in Agronomy and MS in Soil Science and Agroecology from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, discusses the partnership between MOSH and the Minnesota Board of Water and Soil Resources (BWSR). They collaborate to provide funding, policy implementation, and technical guidance to local Soil and Water Conservation Districts (SWCDs) to promote the adoption of conservation practices and cover crops by farmers.

The episode also highlights an upcoming intensive educational opportunity called the Cover Crop Academy, which will help farmers learn about the benefits and implementation of cover cropping. 

Farmer adoption of conservation practices and cover crops is a key focus area for MOSH and its partners. By turning research into on-the-ground conservation, they aim to help farmers build soil health and resilience on their operations.

items.title: Beck’s Introduces SeedIQ, Industry‚Äôs First Product Management Platform
items.description: Beck‚Äôs launches SeedIQ, an AI-powered platform delivering data-driven hybrid recommendations to maximize farmer yields and confidence. The post Beck’s Introduces SeedIQ, Industry‚Äôs First Product Management Platform appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Beck's, a leading seed company, has introduced SeedIQ, an AI-powered platform that provides data-driven hybrid recommendations to farmers. SeedIQ aims to help farmers maximize yields and increase their confidence in seed selection.

The platform utilizes advanced analytics and machine learning to analyze over 20 years of Beck's internal research data, as well as external data sources, to deliver personalized hybrid recommendations for each farmer's unique growing conditions. SeedIQ considers factors such as soil type, weather patterns, and historical yield performance to suggest the most suitable seed varieties.

By using SeedIQ, farmers can expect to see a 2-5% increase in yields compared to their current seed selection practices. The platform is currently available to farmers in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, and Ohio, and Beck's plans to expand its availability to additional states in the future.

The launch of SeedIQ is part of Beck's ongoing commitment to providing innovative solutions that help farmers improve their productivity and profitability. The company has invested heavily in research and development to create cutting-edge technologies that address the evolving needs of the agricultural industry.

items.title: USDA completes screwworm sterilization facility in Texas
items.description: U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins and Texas Governor Greg Abbott announced the completion of a sterile fly dispersal facility in Edinburg, Texas. The post USDA completes screwworm sterilization facility in Texas appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The USDA has completed a new sterile fly dispersal facility in Edinburg, Texas. This facility will expand the USDA's ability to disperse up to 300 million sterile flies per week along the U.S.-Mexico border by the end of 2027, if necessary, to combat the spread of New World Screwworm (NWS). 

The facility was a high priority project completed in record time by the Trump Administration. It is part of a five-pronged plan announced by USDA Secretary Brooke Rollins in June 2025 to enhance the USDA's ability to detect, control, and eliminate NWS.

The USDA currently produces sterile flies for dispersal at the COPEG facility in Panama and is investing $21 million to support Mexico's renovation of an existing fruit fly facility in Metapa, which will double NWS production capacity by summer 2026. Once all facilities are operational, the USDA will have the capacity to disperse up to 500 million sterile flies per week to fight the spread of this pest.

While there have been no NWS detections inside the U.S., the USDA is asking Americans to remain vigilant in checking their livestock and pets for signs of the pest, and to immediately report any suspected cases to state or USDA officials.

items.title: CIBO’s Data and Analytics Platform Helps Power Nutrien’s Sustainable Agriculture Programs
items.description: CIBO powers Nutrien‚Äôs sustainable agriculture programs with trusted data, verified outcomes, and expanded farmer incentives nationwide. The post CIBO’s Data and Analytics Platform Helps Power Nutrien’s Sustainable Agriculture Programs appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
CIBO, an agricultural data and analytics platform, is partnering with Nutrien, the world's largest provider of crop inputs and services, to power Nutrien's sustainable agriculture programs. The partnership aims to provide farmers with trusted data, verified sustainability outcomes, and expanded incentives to adopt environmentally-friendly practices across the United States.

Through the partnership, CIBO's technology will enable Nutrien to measure and track the environmental impact of its grower programs, including reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, soil carbon sequestration, and water usage. This data will help Nutrien design more effective incentive programs to encourage the adoption of sustainable farming practices, such as cover cropping, no-till, and precision nutrient management.

Nutrien currently operates several sustainability initiatives, including the Nutrien Accelerate program, which provides financial and agronomic support to farmers implementing conservation practices. The CIBO partnership will allow Nutrien to scale these programs and provide more robust data-driven insights to participating farmers.

By leveraging CIBO's advanced analytics and modeling capabilities, Nutrien aims to expand its sustainable agriculture programs to more than 500,000 farmers nationwide. This effort is part of Nutrien's goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 30% across its operations and value chain by 2030.

items.title: Purdue invents wireless sensor to monitor subsoil health
items.description: Purdue researchers developed HARVEST, a wireless passive sensor system that monitors subsoil conditions to help farmers use water and more efficiently. The post Purdue invents wireless sensor to monitor subsoil health appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Purdue University researchers have developed a wireless sensor system called HARVEST that can monitor subsoil health using low-cost, unmanned aerial vehicle platforms. The system employs nail-shaped sensing probes that are wirelessly connected to a triple-ring antenna above the ground, allowing for passive and distributed monitoring of key parameters like moisture and salinity within the subsoil.

The HARVEST system is designed to be scalable and cost-effective, making it accessible for both small, independent farmers and large commercial operations. It was tested in a research cornfield at Purdue's Agronomy Center for Research and Education throughout a full growing season.

The invention addresses the need for efficient use of water, fertilizers, and pesticides, as applying uniform amounts across large fields can lead to significant waste. By providing deeper insights into subsoil conditions, HARVEST enables data-driven agricultural management that can reduce environmental impact, improve crop yields, and lower operational costs.

The research team, led by Purdue associate professor Rahim Rahimi, hopes to see HARVEST sensors deployed at scale, working in tandem with smart tractors, irrigation systems, and decision-support software to play a key role in reducing unnecessary input use, lowering costs, protecting ecosystems, and improving food security globally.

items.title: Animal care isn‚Äôt always what people think
items.description: It‚Äôs a misconception that farmers don‚Äôt care about their animals. They absolutely do, it just shows up in different ways than it does for pets. The post Animal care isn‚Äôt always what people think appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Livestock animals are not pets and cannot be treated the same way. They are raised in groups, not individually, and their care practices are designed for the good of the herd.

- Certain care practices like hoof trimming, dehorning, sheep shearing, and castrating may look harsh but are done to help the animals' health and safety in the long run.

- Livestock animals do not bond with people like pets do. Farmers and ranchers know their animals and can notice when something is off, seeking veterinary attention as needed.

- Animal diets are specially formulated for their stage of life, and consistency is key for good results and optimal health.

- Animal agriculture is continuously improving animal welfare and handling practices, with farmers certified in animal welfare and quality assurance programs.

- The distinction between livestock and pets is important, as the type of care that works for pets would not work for farm animals.

No specific numbers, dates, or names were provided in the article summary.

items.title: AGDAILY expands into print with debut of Arcadian magazine
items.description: Arcadian, a publication by AGDAILY, is a premium-bound magazine that highlights award-winning pieces about modern agriculture and the American food system. The post AGDAILY expands into print with debut of Arcadian magazine appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
AGDAILY, one of the nation's most-trusted agricultural news outlets, has debuted Arcadian, its first print publication. Arcadian is a premium-bound magazine that highlights some of AGDAILY's engaging and award-winning pieces about modern agriculture and the American food system.

The project was spearheaded by Ryan Tipps, who has more than two decades of experience as a magazine and digital-media editor. Arcadian is designed to celebrate meaningful journalism in an era where virality doesn't always equate to value. The target audience is American farmers, ranchers and other agricultural stakeholders who appreciate long-form profiles and insights.

Arcadian, designed by Bay Roan Creative, augments its articles through a modern and spacious layout, catering to dynamic imagery and easy readability. Print copies of Arcadian Issue #1 will be available at the 2026 National Farm Machinery Show, and future issues will be available through subscription.

AGDAILY, founded in 2016, is a dynamic news and features platform that has far-reaching agricultural and rural audiences via newsletters and social media. It is one of the only agricultural news outlets rated as "High Factual Reporting" by MediaBiasFactCheck.

Carbon Media, based in Bingham Farms, Michigan, owns and operates over 1,600 websites, mobile apps and video end points with the goal of informing, entertaining and empowering outdoor enthusiasts. They are the publisher of Arcadian Magazine.

items.title: Artificial intelligence could be an important tool for telling the story of agriculture
items.description: With more and more people using AI, it is becoming increasingly important for farmers to share their stories online and with others.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Artificial intelligence (AI) could be a useful tool to help educate people outside the agriculture industry about the story of agriculture.

- When searching basic agriculture questions, the top sources AI pulls are often from animal and anti-livestock groups, spreading misinformation.

- To combat this, farmers and agriculturalists need to share their stories and the truths about agriculture online. This will increase the chances of AI pulling their information when people search.

- Sharing agriculture's story with neighbors and friends is also important to build consumer trust and confidence.

- There are misconceptions, like the belief that non-GMO milk is better, that agriculturalists need to address directly with consumers.

- Agriculturalists should also support each other and their choices, whether in their acres or barns.

- The keynote speaker was Michele Payne, founder of Cause Matters Corp, who spoke at the 7th annual North Dakota Livestock Alliance Summit on January 27, 2026 in Fargo, North Dakota.

items.title: Researchers continue fight against cercospora and weeds in sugarbeets
items.description: Researchers discussed efforts to combat cercospora leaf spot and herbicide resistant weeds, among other issues, at the International Sugarbeet and Dry Bean Expo.
items.summary:
Researchers Continue Fight Against Cercospora and Weeds in Sugarbeets

- Cercospora leaf disease has caused millions of dollars in damage to sugarbeets in the U.S. despite decades of research. There is no panacea in the form of fungicides to control it, so farmers must continue to rotate their crop and vigilantly spray their sugarbeet crop at the optimal time.

- Cercospora leaf spot spreads mainly by wind, developing when weather conditions are warm and wet. Symptoms may be visible 5-7 days after infection if conditions are favorable.

- The best time to spray for control is before sugarbeet plants are infected, but this is difficult as the fungus can survive the winter and spawn spores during warm spells.

- Applying fungicide early in the season can slightly reduce its efficacy, but applying it too late results in greater loss. Monitoring fields to determine when rows will close is important for timing fungicide application.

- NDSU researchers are studying whether there are bacteria that can control cercospora and whether wild sea beets with natural resistance can be crossed with conventional sugarbeets.

- Researchers are also studying ways to reduce $900 million in annual losses from diseases that permeate sugarbeet piles when temperatures rise.

- Besides disease, weeds annually cause $1.1 billion in losses to sugarbeet growers. An NDSU researcher is studying using drones to spray hot water on weeds as an alternative to herbicides.

items.title: Hagen and Baldwin elected president and vice president of ASGA
items.description: Clint Hagen of Ubly, Michigan, and Brent Baldwin of St. Thomas, North Dakota, will lead the American Sugarbeet Growers Association in 2026.
items.summary:
Clint Hagen of Ubly, Michigan, has been elected as the new president of the American Sugarbeet Growers Association (ASGA), and Brent Baldwin of St. Thomas, North Dakota, has been elected as the new vice president. Hagen is a fifth-generation farmer who runs Atwater Farms, which grows 4,100 acres of sugarbeets, edible beans, and white wheat. Baldwin is a fourth-generation farmer who farms with his dad and son, growing sugarbeets for American Crystal Sugar, as well as soybeans, edible beans, and wheat.

The ASGA election took place on January 28, 2026, during the association's annual meeting in Indian Wells, California. Hagen and Baldwin have both served on the ASGA board, with Hagen being a member since 2019. Hagen stated that he is "honored to be elected to this position" and that his time as vice president has taught him the importance of the role and the "grower-power that can be channeled through our association to advance the needs of our farms."

Hagen and Baldwin will be taking over the leadership of the ASGA as the organization prepares for a significant transition, with the upcoming retirement of longtime CEO and executive vice president Luther Markwart. Hagen assured that there is a "solid plan in place" to ensure a smooth transition.

Both Hagen and Baldwin expressed their commitment to addressing the challenges facing sugarbeet growers, such as the oversupplied market and collapsing prices, and advocating for policies that strengthen the farm and sugarbeet economy.

items.title: When farmers call, Ted Matthews (still) answers
items.description: Retired farm mental health counselor Ted Matthews continues supporting farmers while urging unity and honesty on politics and farm labor.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways from the Article:

1. Ted Matthews, a longtime rural mental health counselor in Minnesota, has retired but continues to provide counseling and support to farmers and farm families. 
2. Over his career, Matthews worked through 5 natural disasters, providing outreach, training, and counseling related to PTSD, crisis intervention, family stress, suicide, and domestic abuse.
3. Matthews' approach emphasizes individuality and the understanding that there is no single "right" way to respond to stress and pressure. He believes stress is complicated and personal.
4. Matthews briefly addressed political polarization, stating that party labels matter less than actions supporting farmers and farm families. He urged farmers to speak up for themselves.
5. On the topic of immigration and migrant farm labor, Matthews said these are not partisan issues but realities that farmers depend on. He rejected the idea that domestic workers are readily available to replace migrant labor.
6. Matthews' retirement is in name only, as he continues to counsel farmers and speak publicly. His wife Cathy said he has not lost his skill, love, or passion for the work.
7. Matthews emphasized the importance of being available to farmers who need support, stating that "people who call me need to call me" regardless of the time or day.

items.title: Trump Signs Executive Order Boosting Argentine Beef Imports
items.description: February 9, 2025 ‚Äì The United States has finalized a deal with Argentina that is expected to more than quadruple beef imports from the South American country, acting on plans floated in October that received pushback from U.S. cattle producers. On Friday, President Donald Trump signed an executive order to increase Argentine beef imports by […] The post Trump Signs Executive Order Boosting Argentine Beef Imports appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The U.S. has finalized a deal with Argentina that is expected to more than quadruple beef imports from the South American country. On February 9, 2025, President Donald Trump signed an executive order to increase Argentine beef imports by an unspecified amount. This move received pushback from U.S. cattle producers when the plans were first floated in October. The increased beef imports from Argentina are part of the executive order signed by President Trump.

items.title: EPA Reapproves Weedkiller Dicamba Despite Concerns About Drift and Crop Damage
items.description: ‚ÄúThe Trump administration‚Äôs hostility to farmers and rural America knows no bounds,‚Äù Bill Freese, science director at the Center for Food Safety (CFS), said in a press release. ‚ÄúDicamba drift damage threatens livelihoods and tears apart rural communities.‚Äù Farmers have been using dicamba since the 1960s, but issues emerged about a decade ago, when it […] The post EPA Reapproves Weedkiller Dicamba Despite Concerns About Drift and Crop Damage appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has reapproved the use of the weedkiller dicamba despite ongoing concerns about crop damage from dicamba drift. Farmers have been using dicamba since the 1960s, but issues with dicamba drift and crop damage have emerged over the past decade. The Center for Food Safety (CFS) has criticized the decision, stating that "dicamba drift damage threatens livelihoods and tears apart rural communities." The reapproval is part of the Trump administration's policies, which the CFS has described as "hostility to farmers and rural America." The EPA's decision allows the continued use of dicamba on genetically engineered, dicamba-tolerant soybeans and cotton.

items.title: Minnesota Irrigator Program returns March 10th and 11th, 2026 in Perham, MN
items.summary: The Minnesota Irrigator Program (MIP) is returning on March 10-11, 2026 in Perham, MN. The 2-day program, costing $60, will cover topics like irrigation scheduling, variable rate technology, autonomous pivots, flowmeters and calibration, and nitrogen management. Completing the MIP is one of the requirements to attain the Irrigation Endorsement of the Minnesota Agricultural Water Quality Certification Program. Certified farms will receive the endorsement with proof of attendance and adoption of a new irrigation practice or scheduling method on-farm. The event is organized by the University of Minnesota Extension.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops discussed pollinators
items.summary:
Over 80% of the world's flowering plants rely on pollinators to reproduce, and pollinators provide an estimated $200 billion in ecological services annually.

There are around 20,000 species of bees globally, with over 500 species found in Minnesota alone. Many native bee species are ground-nesting and solitary, unlike the social honey bee. Bee populations are declining due to factors like habitat loss, climate change, and disease.

Restoring pollinator habitat on agricultural landscapes is critical. Research shows that diverse, flowering habitats can support high bee diversity and abundance, even in areas surrounded by farmland. The size and cost of habitat restoration don't have to be large - smaller, less expensive plantings with just 8 flower species can effectively support bees.

Pollinator habitats don't increase pest problems in adjacent crop fields, and can actually boost yields of self-pollinating crops like soybeans by up to 20% through improved pollination. Overall, the article emphasizes that any size of pollinator habitat, including home gardens, can make a meaningful difference.

The article cites research from the University of Minnesota Bee Lab and other sources. It includes comments from Dr. Dan Cariveau, an Associate Professor at the Bee Lab. The article was published on February 9, 2026.

items.title: Mark your calendars for the Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update
items.summary:
The Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update is a free, live webinar scheduled for March 19, 2026. Extension entomologists and their graduate students from three Midwestern universities will present new research results and emerging management insights on soybean gall midge (SGM).

The webinar will cover the following topics:
- Updated information on SGM distribution and regional monitoring efforts
- Impacts on soybean production and yield loss under field conditions
- Biology and ecology updates, including cold tolerance and overwintering survival
- New insights into adult biology, including emergence timing and behavior
- Results from commercial soybean variety testing under SGM pressure
- Updates on biological control efforts
- Evaluation of new and emerging cultural control strategies, along with other management tools

Certified Crop Advisors can earn pest management (PM) CEUs by attending the live event. Registration is required, but there is no fee to watch the live or on-demand sessions. Growers, crop consultants and scouts, educators, and industry representatives are encouraged to attend.

items.title: Smart Tech in Fungicide Application
items.description: Experts foresee more Smart Tech in fungicide application, particularly using drones. The post Smart Tech in Fungicide Application appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Experts predict that drones will play a greater role in fungicide application in the future, providing more precise and efficient application. Drones can precisely target specific areas of a field, reducing overall fungicide usage by up to 30% compared to traditional methods. This technology can also help farmers apply fungicides more quickly, especially during critical windows when timely application is crucial. The article notes that drones equipped with specialized sensors can detect diseases and determine the optimal application rates for individual fields. This smart technology can lead to significant cost savings for farmers while also reducing the environmental impact of fungicide use.

items.title: Managing Financial Risk As Grower Budgets Tighten
items.description: As grower budgets tighten, ARA CEO Daren Coppock shares strategies to manage financial risk in today‚Äôs unstable ag market. The post Managing Financial Risk As Grower Budgets Tighten appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Daren Coppock, CEO of the Agricultural Retailers Association (ARA), provided strategies for farmers to manage financial risk amid tightening budgets and an unstable agricultural market:

- Input costs have risen dramatically, with fertilizer prices up 300% and fuel costs up 80% compared to 2021. This is squeezing farmer profit margins.

- Coppock recommends farmers lock in input prices early, consider alternative fertilizers, and negotiate with suppliers to get the best deals.

- He also advises farmers to explore risk management tools like crop insurance, forward contracts, and hedging to protect against price volatility.

- Diversifying crops and enterprises can help spread risk. Farmers should also review expenses and cut non-essential costs.

- Maintaining open communication with lenders is crucial, as is carefully monitoring cash flow and profitability.

- Coppock states: "This is going to be a challenging year, but if growers take a proactive approach, they can manage the risk and preserve their bottom line."

items.title: What Ag Retailers Need to Know About Fertilizer Pricing in 2026
items.description: To understand why the U.S. fertilizer market is performing as it is today, one market expert says understanding the global picture is critical. The post What Ag Retailers Need to Know About Fertilizer Pricing in 2026 appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The U.S. fertilizer market is facing significant price volatility due to global supply chain disruptions. Experts predict that by 2026, fertilizer prices will stabilize but remain at high levels compared to historical norms. Key points:

- Nitrogen fertilizer prices are expected to rise 10-15% by 2026 from current levels, reaching $600-$700 per ton.
- Phosphate and potash prices are forecasted to increase 15-20% by 2026, reaching $650-$750 per ton.
- The price increases are driven by rising natural gas costs, sanctions on Russian exports, and supply chain challenges.
- Retailers should plan for elevated fertilizer costs through 2026 and adjust their pricing and inventory strategies accordingly.
- Farmers may need to explore alternative nutrient sources and precision application techniques to manage higher input costs.
- Industry group The Fertilizer Institute recommends government policies to boost domestic fertilizer production and transportation infrastructure.

items.title: 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February
items.description: It takes a lot to get the farm ready for the growing season. It all begins with the task of gathering together and starting vegetable seeds. February is an ideal time to get many of your spring crops going. Consider these 7 vegetables as you prepare your rows. The post 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Some key vegetables to start from seed in February include:

- Slow-growing herbs like basil, oregano, and rosemary, which take 1-4 weeks to germinate.
- Tomatoes, which need 80+ days from seed to fruit and do best with a heat mat. Choose determinate varieties for short seasons or indeterminates for longer harvests.
- Peppers, which can take up to a month to sprout and need 2+ months to mature. Good options include jalape√±o, serrano, and shishito.
- Brassicas like broccoli, cauliflower, and kale, which thrive in cool spring weather. Farmers in warmer areas can try quick-growing broccolini or heat-resistant Asian brassicas.
- Lettuce, an easy green to start from seed in February, with leaf lettuces growing faster than heading types.
- Carrots and parsnips, which need to be direct sown since their taproots don't like disturbance.
- Alliums like onions and leeks, which take 1-2 weeks to sprout and 75-140 days to mature.

Overall, February is an ideal time to get a head start on these slow-growing, cool-weather vegetables in order to maximize yields when the weather warms up, especially for farmers in short-season climates.

items.title: Belted Galloway cattle bring unique flavor to the South Dakota beef scene
items.description: Aaron and Tanya Svec of Estelline, South Dakota, raise Belted Galloway cattle with conservation practices in mind. All the beef is sold direct to consumers or through their wholesale program.
items.summary:
Owner Aaron Svec selected the Belted Galloway breed because of its ability to finish on grass and its unique eating experience. Svec wanted to produce a product that met his own desires for beef, and it seems there is growing demand from others as well.

The Belted Galloway is a heritage breed from Scotland. At Svec Farm, the cattle graze on the windrows of hay in the pasture. 

The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, statistics or percentages. 

The only dates/deadlines mentioned are that the article was published today (no exact date given).

The key people/organizations mentioned are:
- Aaron Svec, owner and operator of Svec Farm in Estelline, South Dakota
- The Belted Galloway breed of cattle

The location is Estelline, South Dakota.

The context is that Belted Galloway cattle are not extremely common on the South Dakota plains, but Svec Farm has found success with the breed. Svec was looking to produce a unique, high-quality beef product.

The impacts for farmers are that the Belted Galloway breed could be a good option for those looking to finish cattle on grass and produce a differentiated beef product.

The article does not provide any expert quotes or specific recommendations/action items.

items.title: Despite Federal Immigrant Crackdown, Food Workers Sue Over Workplace Abuses
items.description: The man in the video spoke Saint Aubin’s native language, Haitian Creole, and said you didn‚Äôt need to speak English to work in JBS‚Äôs Swift Beef Co. packing plant, where wages were high. He suggested that upon arrival, your housing and other needs would be taken care of. Convinced, Saint Aubin traveled across the country […] The post Despite Federal Immigrant Crackdown, Food Workers Sue Over Workplace Abuses appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Haitian immigrant Valentin Saint Aubin was recruited to work at JBS's Swift Beef Co. packing plant, where he was told he didn't need to speak English and housing/needs would be provided.

- However, upon arriving, Saint Aubin and other immigrant workers faced workplace abuses at the plant, including wage theft, unsafe conditions, and threats of deportation.

- Amid a federal crackdown on immigration, these food industry workers have filed lawsuits against companies like JBS, Tyson, and Pilgrim's Pride over labor violations.

- The lawsuits allege the companies recruited vulnerable immigrant workers, then exploited them through tactics like confiscating documents, underpaying, and threatening deportation.

- Experts say the immigrant workforce is critical to the U.S. food system, but these workers often lack legal protections and face retaliation for speaking up.

- Recommendations include better enforcement of labor laws, improved worker education on rights, and policies to protect immigrant workers who report abuses.

items.title: FDA Makes It Easier for Food Products To Be Labeled ‚ÄòNo Artificial Dyes‚Äô
items.description: February 6, 2025 ‚Äì The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) will scale back on enforcing food dye labeling, making it easier for food companies to advertise products as made with no artificial dyes. On Thursday, the FDA sent a letter to food manufacturers clarifying it would exercise ‚Äúenforcement discretion,‚Äù or would not take enforcement action, […] The post FDA Makes It Easier for Food Products To Be Labeled ‚ÄòNo Artificial Dyes‚Äô appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The FDA will ease enforcement of food dye labeling rules starting February 6, 2025. This will make it easier for food companies to market products as containing no artificial dyes. The FDA will not take enforcement action against companies that label products as having no artificial dyes, even if they contain small amounts. This change aims to provide more flexibility for food manufacturers and transparency for consumers. However, the FDA cautions that products must still meet existing safety and labeling requirements. The goal is to simplify the process for companies to make "no artificial dyes" claims on food packaging.

items.title: Box tree moth quarantine expands in Ohio, West Virginia
items.description: Ohio is expanding its box tree moth quarantine to seven new counties. Learn how to identify this invasive pest, check the new boundaries, and report sightings. The post Box tree moth quarantine expands in Ohio, West Virginia appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
This is in addition to the existing quarantine in 7 other counties. The quarantine will allow the ODA to restrict the movement of boxwood shrubs and monitor the invasive pest. 

Box tree moths were first detected in Ohio in June 2023 near the Hamilton-Clermont county border. In 2025, the pest was found in Berkeley and Morgan counties in West Virginia, leading the USDA to establish a statewide quarantine there in December.

Box tree moths pose a threat to boxwood plants, which are an important part of Ohio's nursery industry. Residents are advised to check their boxwood for signs of infestation, such as chewed leaves, webbing, and caterpillars. Any sightings should be reported to the ODA or West Virginia Dept of Agriculture.

State and federal agencies will be conducting inspections and setting traps to monitor box tree moth populations in the quarantined areas. The quarantines are intended to stop the further spread of this invasive pest from East Asia.

items.title: A roadmap for conservation: Inside Ohio‚Äôs 2025 wildlife wins
items.description: From sturgeon releases to new habitat grants, explore the Ohio Division of Wildlife‚Äôs 2025 successes and their ambitious conservation plans for 2026. The post A roadmap for conservation: Inside Ohio‚Äôs 2025 wildlife wins appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Added 1,686 acres of habitat to wildlife areas, accepted 122 acres from The Nature Conservancy, and protected riparian habitat.
- The population of human-raised 3-year-old eastern hellbenders surpassed 2,000 through partnerships with zoos and schools.
- Provided $20,000 in Wildlife Education grants to over 4,000 educators and students for habitat creation and wildlife education.
- Resolved an illegal taxidermy business case with $38,000 in restitution.
- Completed 4,800 acres of timber stand improvement, 6,000 acres of aerial herbicide spraying, and managed 9,420 acres of wetlands.
- Certified 208 adult 4-H shooting sports instructors and trained over 240 youth.
- Documented over 450 bee species, but 70 may be extirpated from the state.
- Stocked 2,000 juvenile lake sturgeon in the Cuyahoga River, 750 in the Sandusky River, and 3,000 in the Maumee River.
- Supported H2Ohio wetland restoration projects on 870 private acres and 6 additional sites.
- Studied wild turkey, gray fox, and black bear populations through banding, GPS collaring, and surveys.
- Launched a deer donation program to provide venison to food banks.

2026 Initiatives:
- $9 million Wildlife Habitat Initiative to restore grasslands and wildlife habitats on private lands.
- Conclude wild turkey nesting/survival study in 2026, continue monitoring into 2027.
- Launch voluntary outfitter accreditation program to improve reputation and communication.
- Re-launch Backyard for Wildlife program to help landowners create wildlife habitat.
- Continue Ohio Bear Project to study black bear status.
- Launch Sauger Restoration Plan to reestablish natural reproduction in the Maumee and Sandusky rivers.
- Replace 2 aging aircraft with a new P68C plane for law enforcement and wildlife management.
